issue.title: Avoid ast deprecation warnings on Python 3.12

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
Fix #10977.

Marking as draft until we can verify the fix on next py312 alpha/beta release.

issue.title: Ignore pytest warnings on 3.12

repository.name: pydantic
repository.description: Data validation using Python type hints

issue.body:
<!-- Thank you for your contribution! -->
<!-- Unless your change is trivial, please create an issue to discuss the change before creating a PR -->
<!-- We're currently in the process of rewriting pydantic in preparation for V2, see https://docs.pydantic.dev/blog/pydantic-v2/. -->
<!-- **Note:** if you're making a pull request to fix pydantic v1.10, please make it against the `1.10.X-fixes` branch. -->

## Change Summary

<!-- Please give a short summary of the changes. -->
I decided to try to run the pydantic test suite against current Python 3.12 to look for issues in typing. I had to ignore these warnings (already tracked in pytest-dev/pytest#10977) first to get the tests to run at all.

Now a lot of tests fail for me locally with errors like

```
E               pytest.PytestUnraisableExceptionWarning: Exception ignored in: None
E               
E               Traceback (most recent call last):
E                 File "/Users/jelle/py/pydantic/pydantic/_internal/_core_utils.py", line 247, in walk
E                   return f(schema.copy(), self._walk)
E                            ^^^^^^^^^^^^^
E               ResourceWarning: Object of type pydantic_core._pydantic_core.SchemaValidator is not untracked before destruction
```

That might be a bug in `pydantic_core` but I haven't investigated further. Still, this PR at least enables running the test suite.

## Related issue number

<!-- Are there any issues opened that will be resolved by merging this change? -->
<!-- WARNING: please use "fix #123" style references so the issue is closed when this PR is merged. -->

## Checklist

* [ ] Unit tests for the changes exist
* [ ] Tests pass on CI and coverage remains at 100%
* [ ] Documentation reflects the changes where applicable
* [ ] `changes/<pull request or issue id>-<github username>.md` file added describing change
  (see [changes/README.md](https://github.com/samuelcolvin/pydantic/blob/master/changes/README.md) for details)
* [ ] My PR is ready to review, **please add a comment including the phrase "please review" to assign reviewers**

issue.title: Fix up support for Python 3.12

repository.name: briefcase
repository.description: Tools to support converting a Python project into a standalone native application.

issue.body:
## Changes
- Enable new tarfile extraction protections in Python 3.12
  - https://docs.python.org/3.12/whatsnew/3.12.html#other-language-changes
  - This applies the new ["data" filter](https://docs.python.org/3.12/library/tarfile.html#tarfile.data_filter) to unpacking tar files
  - This prevents the unpacked files from using absolute filepaths or symlinks from referencing absolute filepaths or filepaths outside of the target directory
  - Additionally, the permissions are sanitized to basically ensure they are sane; e.g. world execute permissions are removed if the owner doesn't have execute permissions.

## Notes
- `DeprecationWarning` from pytest for `ast` constants
  - https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/10977
- `DeprecationWarning` from dateutil for `datetime.utcfromtimestamp()` usage
  - https://github.com/dateutil/dateutil/issues/1284

## PR Checklist:
<!--- Go over all the following points, and put an `x` in all the boxes that apply. -->
- [x] All new features have been tested
- [x] All new features have been documented
- [x] I have read the **CONTRIBUTING.md** file
- [x] I will abide by the code of conduct

issue.title: Python 3.12 Support

repository.name: urllib3
repository.description: urllib3 is a user-friendly HTTP client library for Python

issue.body:
### Subject

Python 3.12b1 has recently been released. Few issues appeared.

### Deprecations

They are ALL indirect deprecations. that can be ignored in the meantime using:

```
'''default:ast\.([a-zA-Z]+) is deprecated and will be removed:DeprecationWarning''',
'''default:Attribute s is deprecated and will be removed in:DeprecationWarning''',
'''default:datetime\.utcfromtimestamp\(\) is deprecated and scheduled for removal in:DeprecationWarning''',
```

The first two are triggered in **pytest** and the last one in python-dateutil.

### References

- https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/10977
- https://github.com/dateutil/dateutil/issues/1284

### Errors

Three tests fail consistently.

```
FAILED test/with_dummyserver/test_proxy_poolmanager.py::TestHTTPProxyManager::test_redirect - assert 500 == 303
 +  where 500 = <urllib3.response.HTTPResponse object at 0x7f9a271f3d30>.status
FAILED test/with_dummyserver/test_proxy_poolmanager.py::TestHTTPProxyManager::test_cross_host_redirect - Failed: DID NOT RAISE <class 'urllib3.exceptions.MaxRetryError'>
FAILED test/with_dummyserver/test_proxy_poolmanager.py::TestHTTPProxyManager::test_cross_protocol_redirect - Failed: DID NOT RAISE <class 'urllib3.exceptions.MaxRetryError'>
```

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/runner/work/urllib3/urllib3/test/with_dummyserver/test_proxy_poolmanager.py", line 222, in test_redirect
    assert r.status == 303
AssertionError: assert 500 == 303
 +  where 500 = <urllib3.response.HTTPResponse object at 0x7f9a271f3d30>.status
```

I suspect that the dev server crashed. I'm afraid I don't have any more details for now.

issue.title: Official support for Python 3.12

labels.name: Housekeeping
labels.description: Code cleanup, removal of deprecated stuff, etc.

milestone.description: Finally letting the dead snakes lie. Also some nice new features.

repository.name: sopel
repository.description: :robot::speech_balloon: An easy-to-use and highly extensible IRC Bot framework. Formerly Willie.

issue.body:
### Requested Feature

Python 3.12 has [entered beta](https://www.python.org/downloads/release/python-3120b1/), so it's a good time to start thinking about Sopel on that version.

* [x] Check Sopel tests against 3.12 (done in #2516)
  * Installing `dev-requirements.txt` was blocked by [lack of support](https://github.com/python-greenlet/greenlet/issues/357) in `greenlet`, but [a PR](https://github.com/python-greenlet/greenlet/pull/327) has since been merged with a fix for this, presumably the next release will include that fix.
  * Looks like we may need to adjust the version requirement for `setuptools`, I see the following error with `setuptools == 67.8.0` but pinning `setuptools < 67` in `build-system.requires` resolves it.  
  ```
  AttributeError: module 'pkgutil' has no attribute 'ImpImporter'. Did you mean: 'zipimporter'?
  ```
  * There was additional upstream breakage that has now been fixed [in `aiohttp`](https://github.com/aio-libs/aiohttp/issues/7229) (fixed on develop, should be included in 3.9) and [in `frozenlist`](https://github.com/aio-libs/frozenlist/issues/433) (released in [1.4.0](https://github.com/aio-libs/frozenlist/releases/tag/v1.4.0))
* [x] Update CI to run with 3.12 (done in #2516)
  * Looks like the `python-versions` Action is [capable of providing the 3.12.0b1 pre-release](https://github.com/actions/python-versions/blob/7693cef3461cf6902845be55593a2328fef3bea3/versions-manifest.json#L3), so we could run against the beta version(s) before the official release ([scheduled](https://peps.python.org/pep-0693/) for 2 October 2023).
* [x] Update classifiers list in `pyproject.toml` (done in #2516)
* ~~[ ] Check on 3.12 support concerns for official non-core plugins~~ Not core's problem  @dgw

issue.title: Testing Python 3.12

labels.name: component: infrastructure
labels.description: Issues related to development scripts, CI, servers, etc.

labels.name: priority: 1 - middle
labels.description: Issues which should be done at some point, but aren't that important.

repository.name: qutebrowser
repository.description: A keyboard-driven, vim-like browser based on Python and Qt.

issue.body:
While we had Python 3.12 in the CI during its Alpha phase (with zero issues), now in the Beta phase it looks like things start breaking in upstream projects. Removing it from CI for now, until upstream issues are fixed. Here is what I ran into:

# pytest

Shows ast deprecation warnings:

- https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/10977
- https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/pull/10894

Hidden by:

```diff
diff --git i/pytest.ini w/pytest.ini
index 46a22c5c8..899118186 100644
--- i/pytest.ini
+++ w/pytest.ini
@@ -63,4 +63,7 @@ filterwarnings =
     default:Test process .* failed to terminate!:UserWarning
     # https://github.com/certifi/python-certifi/issues/170
     ignore:path is deprecated\. Use files\(\) instead\. Refer to https.//importlib-resources\.readthedocs\.io/en/latest/using\.html#migrating-from-legacy for migration advice\.:DeprecationWarning:certifi.core
+    # Python 3.12: https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/10977
+    ignore:ast\.(Str|NameConstant|Num) is deprecated and will be removed in Python 3\.14; use ast\.Constant instead:DeprecationWarning
+    ignore:Attribute s is deprecated and will be removed in Python 3\.14; use value instead:DeprecationWarning
 faulthandler_timeout = 90

```

# hypothesis

Triggers syntax error:

- https://github.com/HypothesisWorks/hypothesis/issues/3665
- https://github.com/HypothesisWorks/hypothesis/issues/3663

I don't really see a way around this, guess we'll need to wait for either Hypothesis or (more likely based on the comment) CPython comes up with a fix for this.

issue.title: new deprecation warnings in Python 3.12

repository.name: werkzeug
repository.description: The comprehensive WSGI web application library.

issue.body:
Starting flask in Python 3.12 raises warnings of deprecations in Python 3.14 within Werkzeug

```default
/Users/anthonyshaw/projects/cpython/.venv-312/lib/python3.12/site-packages/werkzeug/routing/rules.py:751: DeprecationWarning: ast.Str is deprecated and will be removed in Python 3.14; use ast.Constant instead
  parts = parts or [ast.Str("")]
/Users/anthonyshaw/projects/cpython/.venv-312/lib/python3.12/site-packages/werkzeug/routing/rules.py:748: DeprecationWarning: ast.Str is deprecated and will be removed in Python 3.14; use ast.Constant instead
  _convert(elem) if is_dynamic else ast.Str(s=elem)
/Users/anthonyshaw/projects/cpython/Lib/ast.py:587: DeprecationWarning: Attribute s is deprecated and will be removed in Python 3.14; use value instead
  return Constant(*args, **kwargs)
/Users/anthonyshaw/projects/cpython/.venv-312/lib/python3.12/site-packages/werkzeug/routing/rules.py:755: DeprecationWarning: ast.Str is deprecated and will be removed in Python 3.14; use ast.Constant instead
  if isinstance(p, ast.Str) and isinstance(ret[-1], ast.Str):
/Users/anthonyshaw/projects/cpython/.venv-312/lib/python3.12/site-packages/werkzeug/routing/rules.py:756: DeprecationWarning: Attribute s is deprecated and will be removed in Python 3.14; use value instead
  ret[-1] = ast.Str(ret[-1].s + p.s)
/Users/anthonyshaw/projects/cpython/.venv-312/lib/python3.12/site-packages/werkzeug/routing/rules.py:756: DeprecationWarning: ast.Str is deprecated and will be removed in Python 3.14; use ast.Constant instead
  ret[-1] = ast.Str(ret[-1].s + p.s)
```

For example:

https://github.com/pallets/werkzeug/blob/76b049dd45fd072fb62a54bccc0e8d513b03f4d8/src/werkzeug/routing/rules.py#L757

The documentation states "Changed in version 3.8: Class [ast.Constant](https://docs.python.org/3/library/ast.html#ast.Constant) is now used for all constants." so I don't know if the `ast.Str` conditions are even working in versions 3.8+.

Considering Werkzeug just dropped support for Python 3.7, the rules code could be refactored to use the new type without breaking compatibility

Environment:

- Python version: 3.12a1
- Werkzeug version: 2.2.3

issue.title: Improve output with invalid asyncio_mode
issue.body:
Instead of a long INTERNALERROR> stack trace, output a proper error
message:

    $ pytest -o asyncio_mode=True
    =================== test session starts ====================
    platform linux -- Python 3.11.3, pytest-7.3.1, pluggy-1.0.0
    ERROR: 'True' is not a valid asyncio_mode

See https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/11083

issue.title: Python 3.12: PyLongObject {aka struct _longobject} has no member named ob_digit
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

We're using yarl in https://github.com/python/blurb_it and are testing against `3.12-dev` on GitHub Actions to help find problems early so they can be fixed before the full release.

With Python 3.12.0a4, yarl-1.8.2.tar.gz installed fine.

With the newest Python 3.12.0a5, yarl-1.8.2.tar.gz fails to install (on Ubuntu). For example:

```
yarl/_quoting_c.c:10674:53: error: PyLongObject {aka struct _longobject} has no member named ob_digit
10674 |             const digit* digits = ((PyLongObject*)x)->ob_digit;
```

Looks like this is the cause: https://github.com/python/cpython/pull/101292 / https://github.com/python/cpython/issues/101291

Here's a similar report for Cython: https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/5238


### To Reproduce

1. With Ubuntu 22.04 (or macOS Ventura 13.2.1) and Python 3.12.0a5
2. `python3.12 -m pip install yarl`

### Expected behavior

yarl installs.

### Logs/tracebacks

```python-traceback

2023-03-01T04:57:42.0820357Z   Building wheel for yarl (pyproject.toml): finished with status 'error'

issue.title: Ignore depr warnings inside pytest on 3.12

repository.name: frozenlist
repository.description: FrozenList is a list-like structure that implements collections.abc.MutableSequence and can be made immutable.

issue.body: These warnings otherwise would abort the test suite. See pytest-dev/pytest#10977.

issue.title: Ignore ast deprecation warnings on Python 3.12
issue.body: Fixes the CI run for Python 3.12 until https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/10977 is addressed in a release.
